It's heart-breaking to think that $3 million can create a little park in the Bronx that can gladden the lives of thousands of people, and that we continue to guilessly spend hundreds and hundreds of billions on 'defense' without giving it a second thought.

I'll second that!  And if you haven't been to the Gardens in a few years, go and see all of the beautiful improvements.  I grew up within walking distance of the Gardens in the 70s and 80s and used to go there all the time (back then it was free to just walk in, and we'd take it as a shortcut from Mosholu Parkway to get over to the Zoo). When I was growing up, a few blocks from the Transit-Mix site, it was always an adventure to walk that part of Westchester Avenue. I can see (and hear) the fleet of trucks even now. Across from the plant there were docks from which deep-sea fishing boats would leave before dawn, in season, taking men from the neighborhood on adventures of their own.

I am deeply touched by the River's recovery, to its state in an era long before mine, as I am by all the renewal in the Bronx.

This story was a delight to me. Thank you.

My memories of the Bronx River, having lived on Bronx Park South in the 1940's, was a river then with a distinctively foul odor. I wonder if anyone recalls the old boat house off Boston Road, just across from the Zoo entrance? My Dad and I and some cousins would rent either an aluminum round bottom or flat botton boat and row north sometimes as far as the original grist mill, which I believe belonged to the P Lorilord tobacco company. The infamous falls had a chain spanning across it to prevent boats from going over. I must have been about 8 or 9 years old when I saw a boy being pulled out of the river by the police. The image hauted me for a long time. Kids would ocassionally attempt to swim across although I was warned of it's danger and seeing that kid being carried by stretcher was a strong reminder that the river was dangerous.
His body was covered, except for his head and long straight black wet hair hanging from the side of the stretcher.
The water as it ran over the falls created a yellow foam that had the odor of sewage.
The article also mentioned Starlight Park, which was the name of the private swimming pool just off West Farms Road and Tremont Avenue. It was our neghborhood "country club" and you got to it by walking behind the old Coliseum which eventually became a trolley barn and later a bus barn.
My Dad claimed that Friday night boxing matches were held there in the1930's.
That's a lot of Bronx history that few people would remember.

Actually I think everyone (regardless of wealth, upstream and downstream) poured their sewerage into the river, and then turned to either reservoirs that were protected or deep wells for drinking/clean water.
NY City suffered badly many many years ago (centuries I believe) with an outbreak of typhus and other water born illnesses before building its reservoir systems. At that time NYC was drawing drinking water from the same ponds and lakes into which they poured their sewerage. Most of New York state now provides some level of sanitation by treating sewerage before disposing of it, still into rivers I believe.
Unfortunately most locations still share waste-water systems with storm water and sewerage, so a big rain will result in overflow of sewerage into whatever is nearby, including streams and rivers.

The article refers to settlements from various upstream suburban communities.  do I undestand from this that they largely dumped their sewage and refuse into the river because those downstream had little money/influence and could have their neighborhoods polluted?

I appreciate the coverage NY times, unlike television, has given special attention to the rebirth of the Bronx parks, waterways and the arts. As an orignal Charlotte Street resident in the bad old days, all we had in SE Bronx was Crotona Park. and Pelham Bay Park by bus or car. We never saw or knew about the Bronx river, except when I moved to Nagle Ave off the FDR Drive on the Manhattan side. I hope this cleans up with oasis parks Orchard Beach bay as well. I love the grassy areas there. The floating pool is a great idea too.

More oak trees and naive rocks also is good design. I notice the change at Bronx botanic garden where birds now flock, Other cleanups included are that Hunts Point food trailers are connected to some special grid for refrigeration.

There is no real estate developer involved. Robert Clemente Park, Yankee Stadium parks. and Randalls Island also have contributed to this revitalization. I can picture these boater teens loving getting away from the din of congested urban neighborhoods.

Lets hope it helps in revitalizing the health and spirits of Bronx youth and its families. Amazing grass roots organizations, kudos.

I plan to visit Barreto Point park. Congressman Serrano's son is a NYS senate and is on the Parks committee and is continuing his father's legacy. I get his news letter. He has been involved in building bridges to randalls island from the bronx and in improving walkable access from Manhattan's FDR. Are bathroom facilities. also being built. Serrano has scheduled festivities in some of these oasis parks to lure the Bronx residents. It is interesting that Bronx residents have behaved respectfully on these new parks unlike Bklyns McCarren Park. Perhaps a sense of community is more solidly anchored in the Bronx.

The old Bronx River, I used to love to go to Bronx Park as a child and go to the falls.There used to be a broom factory and I think they used the river in those days for energy for the plant. They need to really fix the Bronx, because it’s a beautiful borough with a huge potential, the Bronx still has that old New York look to it or even in some parts a touch of Europe. The Architecture of most the buildings are old European style, with the Gargoyles and Angels ornamenting some of the buildings. The Bronx has more parks then any other borough. The Bronx also is the only Borough attached to the U.S. mainland. I love the Bronx and it holds great memories.
if you've not seen any of these amazing developments, if you've never been to the bronx, if you've never been to the south bronx i say: GO! you won't be disappointed!

If the US had provided anything but vague moral support to the Greens in Iran, it would have played right into the hands of those who said the US wanted to expand their influence (take over).  It was practically the rallying cry for supporters of the status quo, already.  It didn't need any cheerleading from our side to amplify the message.

It's not entirely clear to me just what assistance, if any, the US is providing to the rebels except to indicate that it is not standing in the way of other countries providing assistance. There's no reason why the US can't be a bit more positive about what it's doing. (The US was roundly criticized for doing absolutely nothing to support Iran's fledgling Green movement except to offer moral encouragement.) As soon as the Russians decide which side is likely to prevail they'll probably join the winning side as they did in Libya.

The rebels have demonstrated a degree of resourcefulness and an ability to take and hold ground (at least for a short time) so I see no reason why they won't eventually prevail. So it is obviously in the interest of the West to try and make that happen before the country is torn to bits by this conflict.

The US should stop worrying about a potential power vacuum and get down to the business at hand - assisting the rebels to prevail. Leaders will emerge as they always do in any conflict. To try to pick leaders at this point just generates divisiveness. (Like Libya, the rebel leaders seem to have no interest in al Qaeda even though some of the extremists sent by Assad to Iraq to kill Americans have returned home to join the opposition movement.)

Despite the out-of-context quotes and clips that appeared nonstop on Fox News, Obama didn't belittle the efforts of small business owners.

All the denials about Obama's intent and about his not offending anyone are pointless.

If they believe his comments were offensive, they were.

Some advice for this president would be for him to not mix insults in with his comments. This way the insult won't overpower the comment.

As an actual independent contractor in the software development industry, I had no trouble recognizing that Obama was not belittling me. Unlike you, Pete (I remember you toeing the same old party line back on fivethirtyeight.com in 2008), I'm capable of being grateful for all the things in my life that have made my success possible that came from the government. Public schools, fine public universities (including research grants that paid my way through graduate school), and of course most importantly the Internet, which allows me to conduct business with customers in Europe and Asia with ease, not to mention myriad other things like the road system, safety regulations, etc. etc. etc.

I find it sad that the same people who love to talk about how America is the greatest country on the face of the planet seem to forget that same rhetoric when it comes to appreciating the role of that in your own success. Instead you act like a spoiled child who talks about how he "earned" his shiny new Mustang all by himself by getting all A's in school. Or to quote the eminently quotable Ann Richards, you were born on third base and think you hit a triple (this is true of all Americans in comparison to the rest of the world). If I have reached high points, it is because I have stood on the backs of giants.

David,
You make a simple point, a tautological truth of sorts -- we are all interdependent. But its a matter of degree.

What was striking about the President's remarks was how far out of the way he went to reject the notion of individual achievement as a component of success -- "lots of people are smart" and "lots of people work hard" indicating that it isn't your ingenuity or hard work that makes for your success, but some other factor -- maybe you were born with a silver spoon in your mouth, perhaps.

We all could be Bill Gates after all we all benefit from government, so he must just be lucky, a random lottery winner, i suppose.

What Mr. Obama was saying is that the role of government is central to our success -- so much so that he mocked individual qualities. In this, in my view, he is far out of touch with what made America great and just as far out of touch with the typical voter who does not feel he or she must rely on government to make their way in our society.

We are not all Julias -- yet!

This is a really interesting theory, though I have to say that I see some truth in it.

If I may, I'd like to propose a reason for this Bradley-like effect (ironically, for the opposite reasons of the original Bradley effect): the dislike of Mitt Romney. It's clearly not popular to be a Mitt Romney supporter, even among Republicans. More people might not be willing to admit to wanting to vote for Romney, even though they may plan to do so. The media's reaction to Romney would, if anything, exacerbate this.

Now, this is obviously idle speculation, though I do like to speculate, and will inevitably continue to do.

Would you care to give some evidence for this purported Bradley Effect?
Nate's look at the polls in early June showed Walker with a lead of about 6 points: http://fivethirtyeight.blogs.nytimes.com/2012/06/04/late-polls-find-walk... .
Walker won by 6.8 points.
Again: given that the polls accurately predicted the race's outcome, where, exactly, is your evidence?

I think shrill dislike of Obama by many in lower economic white ranks, through persuasion of right wing radio and cable jocks, no longer allow for necessity of hiding behind Bradley.  People are far more comfortable having their dislike for someone of President Obama's ilk even more than in 2008.

Do you have an analysis for Wisconsin in June? There was a pronounced Bradley effect that continued through the exit polls. Well, Bradley-like effect as in reflected union support rather than race. However, the use of both in our current political landscape are highly coupled.

There has been 4+ years of the media building the Bradley effect. Most recently, in the media's response to Romney's NAACP appearance. The one occasion of scattered booing vs. the 17 interruptions for applause and the standing ovation at the end. The way it was covered by the press subsequently.

If the Bradley effect in November is the same as it was in Wisconsin in June, Romney is up 4 points nationally and in virtually every contested state.

The internals in the New Mexico poll were very interesting. The President, according to the poll, has lost support among Democrats in the state and even more alarmingly for him has seen a significant decline in his Hispanic support. How can this be?

It's really pretty simple: NM is on the front lines of the Mexican drug wars, and like AZ, CA and TX it bears the brunt of the immigration problem our porous border with Mexico brings. The problems in the Border States are so acute that even Democrats there are revolting against an immigration policy that will only exacerbate the problem.

The reaction among Hispanics is frankly predictable as well. The President’s policy is aimed to benefit non-citizens. The Hispanics who vote are a fortiori citizens and don’t need the promised liberalization. And while the new policy may signal a sort of amity towards people with whom they share a cultural identity, the more immediate impact for Hispanics is to worsen their own job situations as they now have some 800,000 to a 1,000,000 more competitors for work that is already in scarce supply. The phenomenon of “pulling the ladder up behind you” has long been remarked on. It would be a mistake that to thing that voting Hispanics would ignore their self-interest any more than other immigrant groups.
